text:
In this video we're going to take a look at the differences
between working with Automation and Modulation
in Ableton Live.

Automation and Modulation are two ways to tell Live
how and when to make changes to parameters.

For example the volume of a track
with a cut-off frequency of a filter.

Automation tells Live to set the parameter to a specific
value at the specific time.
In Session View, Automation is displayed within Clips.

We can draw in automation using either the Pencil tool
or by selecting a shape from the menu

that pops up when we right-click on a PC
or Ctrl + Click on a Mac.

Alternatively we can record in automation using a Push,
a MIDI controller or even your mouse or track-pad.
Let's record in some automation on this Delay device.

Once a parameter has been automated
Live will display a red dot next to it.

Modulation also tells Live how and when to move
parameters.

However, with Modulation, the movement is always relative
to a parameter's current value.

Sometimes it's helpful to think of Modulation as a way
to scale the range of parameter changes.

Here I have a long bass note, with some simple automation
drawn in, which we can see in red.

Clicking the Modulation button, I'm going to draw in a ramp
with the blue line that goes from low to high
as my clip progresses.

As you can hear, the automation provides some movement,
while the modulation defines how much of that movement
is applied to the filter.

The effect that the automation has on the sound
becomes more dramatic.

Automation and Modulation can work together
to produce interesting results.

In this clip I've drawn in some Modulation
for Wavetable's filter, but I haven't yet used Automation.

This way I'm free to experiment with the filter's cut-off
position whilst always retaining my modulation pattern.

If I find an idea I like, I can capture it by recording in
the automation.

As well as using Clip View to access these features
we can also use a shortcut via a pop-up menu

anywhere in Live's interface. Simply select a clip,
navigate to the parameter we want to work with,
and right-click on a PC or Ctrl + Click on a Mac.
